title.narrative: Malawi - Financial Sector Technical Assistance Project

description.narrative: The project aims to increase access to finance for the currently unbanked, but bankable, population of Malawi.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Finance, Economic Planning and Development

sector.narrative: Financial Sector oversight and policy/banking regulation & restructuring

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :-Schedule, Sec.IA.1(b) of PA | Description :By not later than 12/31/11 establish and operationalize the FSTAPPIU, andthereafter ensure that the responsibilities carried outby the BESTAP PIU are efficientlytransferred to the PIU. | DueDate :31-Dec-2011

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Sec.1.E of FA | Description :No withdrawal shall be made for payments prior to the date of the FA;and for consultant services for the MFDT unlessand until it has been established referred to in Sec.I.E of Sch.2 fo the FA |Frequency :Quarterly

Finance Agreement :Sec. II. B1 of PA | Description :Maintain adequate financial management system and records; preparefinancialstatements of operations, resources and expenditures of the project. | Frequency :Quarterly
Finance Agreement :Sec. II. B2 of PA | Description :Furnish unaudited interim financial reports (IFRs) no later than 45 days afterthe end ofeach accounting quarter. | Frequency :Quarterly
Finance Agreement :Sec. II. B2 of PA | Description :Submit to the Bank audited financial statements not later than 6 months afterthe end ofthe project. | Frequency :Yearly

title.narrative: PDO Indicator Two: Increase in the proportion of women within the adult population that is formally banked.
PDO Indicator One: Increase in the percentage of the adult population that use formal financial institutions.
Indictor One: Key regulations and supervision manuals issued to support implementation of the 10 new financial laws which have beenpassed recently or to be passed over the life of the project.

baseline.value: Existing regulatory framework needs to be upgraded in order to support the implementation of the 7 new laws passed in the last 2years, in addition to the 3 new bills that are expected to be passed later

target.value: Key regulations and supervision manuals developed and issued to support implementation of 10 new financial laws which had passed atthe start and over the life of the project

actual.value: Regulations related to the 10 laws that were passed from March 2009 have either been issued or are at gazetting stage

title.narrative: Indicator Three: RBM staff trained in uses of analytical tools and regarding new regulations (text, custom breakdown)

baseline.value: No automated analytical tools are available and staff do not have hands on experience using them

target.value: 100% of staff trained

actual.value: All relevant staff trained in the enhanced BSA

title.narrative: Sub-indicator Four (c): Transactions volume and value processed by MFI Hub (numeric/percentage, custom)

baseline.value: None: no MFI Hub existed

target.value: At least 5 institutions to go live by June 2018

actual.value: Being implemented

title.narrative: Sub-indicator Four (b): Transactions volume and value processed by National Switch (numeric/percentage, custom)

baseline.value: None: no interoperable switch existed

target.value: Volume: 5,399,428 (936%) Value (MK bn): Deliberately not defined

actual.value: Volume: 5,390,276 Value (MK bn): 83.51

title.narrative: Indicator Two: Automated tools for offsite surveillance and macro-prudential analysis designed, acquired and implemented.

baseline.value: Offsite and macro-prudential analysis is not supported by automated analytical tools using comprehensive reliable and timely data

target.value: Analytical tools for offsite monitoring and analysis used in day-to-day work.Stability Report updated and published at leastAnnually

actual.value: The Bank Supervision Application (BSA) was enhanced to include non-bank financial institutions; the enhancement was completed inJune 2017.Financial stability reports are being published

title.narrative: Sub-Indicator 4(c): Microfinance Transaction Hub deployed and operational

baseline.value: Outdated financial infrastructure

target.value: Installation, commissioning and stabilization of MFI Transaction Processing Hub (TPH) solution.

actual.value: Data migration and verification completed for 16 pilot institutions.System (software) acceptable to the users.

title.narrative: Sub-indicator 4(a): National Switch deployed and operational

baseline.value: Outdated financial infrastructure

target.value: National Switch live and operational.MNOs and MFI Hub integrated on the National Switch

actual.value: Modern National Switch live and operational. Interoperability has been achieved for ATMs and POS

baseline.value: Outdated financial infrastructure.

target.value: ATS live and operational.

actual.value: ATS live since December 2014 and operating smoothly

title.narrative: Indicator Four: Modern financial infrastructure deployed and operational

baseline.value: See sub indicator below

target.value: See sub indicator below

actual.value: See sub indicator below

title.narrative: PDO Indicator Four: Transactions volume and value processed by new payments systems (ATS, National Switch, MFI TPH)

baseline.value: See sub-indicator below

target.value: See sub-indicator below

actual.value: See sub-indicator below

title.narrative: Sub-indicator Four (a): Transactions volume and value processed by ATS (numeric/percentage, custom)

baseline.value: Volume: 2,080,441 Value (MK bn): 3,415

actual.value: Volume: 21,220,986 Value (MK bn): 73,415

title.narrative: Indicator 10: Increased awareness of rights as financial consumers among population reached by financial literacy campaign (text, custom)

baseline.value: Consumer rights in financial services is a nascent concept and measurement of awareness of the rights needs to be developed throughBaseline survey. No systematic financial literacy campaign has been conducted in Malawi.

target.value: Consumer rights awareness: Baseline+15%Financial literacy campaign: 100% of targeted population reached

actual.value: During the baseline, 36.2% of the population was not aware of government agencies that can be approached for financial servicesrelated complaints

title.narrative: Indicator 14: Policy frameworks for provision of long term financing developed; including (i) equity and debt/leasing financing, (ii) PPP for infrastructure, and (iii) development of long term savings

baseline.value: Long term financing is a nascent concept in Malawi and no systematic analysis has been carried out on the subject matter

target.value: Policy framework adoptedDetailed sectoral reviews completed (pensions, insurance, credit guarantees, and leasing studies)

actual.value: Issues paper on long term finance was developed and long term finance policy was drafted.A consultancy on long term financeguarantee scheme was completed and an action plan on the same was drafted. A framework for investment of pension funds was alsodeveloped.Development of a leasing framework did not proceed as a thorough and analytical study of the Malawi market was notcompleted due to poor quality work, which led to the cancellation of the contract

title.narrative: Indicator 12: State ownership policy in financial sector developed, published, and implemented (text, custom)

baseline.value: No explicit state-ownership policy has been issued

target.value: State ownership policy implemented issuance of parastatal guarantees, indemnities, and letters of consent and comfort underimplementation

actual.value: Ownership regulations for statutory bodies in Malawi, SOE guidelines on overdraft limits, feedback from the Ministry ofJusticeDeveloped SOE guidelines on overdraft limits, issuance of parastatal guarantees, indemnities, and letters of consent andcomfort.

title.narrative: Indicator 7: Approved road-map for implementation of government EFT payment program (text, custom)

baseline.value: No roadmap for implementation of government EFT payment program

target.value: Broad-based ownership and acceptance of an 18-month action plan for government EFT payment programAll (60%) payment interfacesunder the Government EFT Action Plan implemented

actual.value: The EFT roadmap finalized and its implementation commenced. Contracts for the development of various interfaces to securegovernment payment streams have been signed and are being implemented.

title.narrative: Indicator 11: RBM institutional capacity has been enhanced for consumer protection supervision (text, custom)

baseline.value: No training or developed processes and procedures to staff

target.value: All existing staff trained (i.e. individual structured training, attachments, study tours, local training workshops)

actual.value: Except for staff employed in the two years prior to the ICR, 100% of staff in the consumer protection unit wastrainedFurthermore, no training was planned for the 8-month extension period to June 2018

title.narrative: Indicator 9: Institutional arrangements for consumer protection in all financial services implemented

baseline.value: RBM's consumer protection unit (CPFL) has been created (but not staffed) within the Microfinance and Capital Markets unit

target.value: Priority measures of institutional strengthening program implemented including sending the ADR Bill to Cabinet

actual.value: The CPFL drafted Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Bill for the Cabinet as a step towards the adoption of a Twin-Peak model tofinancial consumer protection

title.narrative: Indicator 13: Core functions of the FSPU (Financial Sector Policy Unit) executed by appropriately trained staff (text, custom)

baseline.value: Role of Ministry of Finance in financial sector policy formulation and monitoring is limited

target.value: 100% of FSPU staff trained and annual business plan targets met

actual.value: No training was planned for the 8-month extension period to June 2018The FSPU has since been combined with Government Pensions toform the Pensions and Financial Sector Policy Division headed by a Director.

title.narrative: Indicator 13: Core functions of the FSPU (Financial Sector Policy Unit) executed by appropriately trained staff (text, custom)

baseline.value: Role of Ministry of Finance in financial sector policy formulation and monitoring is limited

target.value: 100% of FSPU staff trained and annual business plan targets met

actual.value: No training was planned for the 8-month extension period to June 2018The FSPU has since been combined with Government Pensions toform the Pensions and Financial Sector Policy Division headed by a Director.

title.narrative: Indicator 8: Legal and regulatory framework for consumer protection prepared and presented to Cabinet (text, custom)

baseline.value: The Financial Services Act includes some major provisions on consumer protection, and gives the RBM authority to regulate andsupervise consumer protection issues in financial services.

target.value: Action plan on financial consumer protection with priorities for legal and regulatory reform implemented in priority phases

actual.value: Third (final) priority regulations drafted; these included market conduct risk-based supervisory guidelines.

title.narrative: Indicator five: Number of participating members of all 3 payment systems (text, custom)

baseline.value: a) Proposed National Switch not yet operational b) Proposed ATS not yet operational c) Proposed MFI TPH not yet operational

target.value: a) 6 banks on National Switch. b) 6 banks on ATS c) Five MFIs and FCs on the MFI TPH

actual.value: a) All 9 banks on National Switch and live on ATMs and POS b) All 9 banks on ATS. Government and MRA are viewing members c) 16MFIs and FC on the MFI TPH pilot to go live by 29th June 2018. Five of them to go live end June 2018

title.narrative: PDO Indicator Three: Agency banking regulations operational
Sub-indicator (c2): Number, value, volume of Bank-led mobile payments (text, custom breakdown)

baseline.value: Number: 176,907 Volume: 3,633,484 Value (MK mn): 3,235

actual.value: Number: 952,702 Volume: 75,072,703 Value (MK mn): 462,439

baseline.value: Number: 185,758 Volume: 698,419 Value (MK bn): 1.40

target.value: Number: Not defined Volume: 11,717,526 (1,678%) Value (MK bn): 158.28 (11,337%)

actual.value: Number: 4,581,992 Volume: 333,395,067 Value (MK bn): 1,022

baseline.value: Number: 373 Volume: 17,217,584 Value (MK bn): 0.170

target.value: Number: Not defined Volume: 23,073,209 (134%) Value (MK bn): 0.302 (177%)

actual.value: Number: 481 Volume: 136,907,780 Value: (MK bn) 2,417

title.narrative: Sub-indicator Six (a): Number, value, volume of POS (text, custom breakdown)

baseline.value: Number: 688 Vol: 183,248 Value (MK mn): 3,548

actual.value: Number: 1,576 Vol: 2,556,541 Value (MK mn): 101,907

title.narrative: Indicator Six: Increased number, value, volume of POS, ATMs and mobile payments (text, custom)

baseline.value: See below

target.value: See below

actual.value: See below

title.narrative: PDO Indicator Six: Proportion of financially literate women in the population (text, custom) - (The values are an index that rangesfrom 0 (illiterate) to 7 (highly literate)
PDO Indicator Five: Proportion of financially literate population (text, custom) (The values are an index that ranges from 0 (illiterate) to 7 (highly literate) based on a baseline survey
